items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
	 
	Presented to the Board for ratification is the list of contracts and agreements signed by the Vice
	Chancellor, Business Services. It is in the intention of Business Services to present such a list
	each month.
	 
	This procedure is in response to a review of Ed Code requirements and the revised board Policy
	Section 3000.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
					 Kevin McElroy, ext. 6201
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided? 
					Yes
items.item_recommendation: Vice Chancellor of Business Services recommends ratification of the contracts and agreements as presented.
items.item_text: Ratification of Contracts and Agreements
items.item_text_raw: 1. Ratification of Contracts and Agreements

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
	The District has 11 pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment (See attached Surplus Forms, 25 pages). The District's Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste.  The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
	California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
	Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers.  Proceeds will be deposited to the District's general fund.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
					Gina Bailey, Interim Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
					Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided? 
					Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).
items.item_text: Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment
items.item_text_raw: 3. Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
	The District owns surplus furniture that has been replaced with new (see attached lists, 5 pages).  The Foothill College, FF&E Coordinator has determined that the furniture is in such poor condition that it is unusable and has estimated that it has no resale value in its current condition.
	 
	California Education Code 81452(c) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those  members present, finds that the property, is of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale, the property may be disposed of in the local public dump on order of any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
	District Staff will dismantle the items and recycle or dispose of the components appropriately.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
					Gina Bailey, Interim Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
					Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
					Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the items are of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to recycle the items of dispose of them in the local public dump.
items.item_text: Recycle and Dispose of Unusable Surplus Furniture
items.item_text_raw: 4. Recycle and Dispose of Unusable Surplus Furniture

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
	De Anza College is continuing its public information and marketing campaign with a view toward maintaining awareness of the college and increasing enrollment, including through promotion of newly added classes and the Eco Pass. Bus ads continue to be a primary advertising medium for the college.
	 
	The Lamar Companies is the agent for bus advertising with the Valley Transit Authority. This contract is for king (side) and full back space rental on VTA buses. The campaign will run from March 4, 2013 through April 14, 2013. It will result in 24,675,847 total impressions of the advertisements. 
	 
	 
Submitted by:
					Brian Murphy, President, ext 8705
Additional contact names:
					Marisa Spatafore, Director of Marketing & Communications, ext 8672
Is backup provided?
					Yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza President Brian Murphy recommends that the Board approve the contract with The Lamar Companies in the amount of $90,500.
items.item_text: Advertising Contract with The Lamar Companies
items.item_text_raw: 6. Advertising Contract with The Lamar Companies

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
	 
	The Student Transfer Achievement Reform Act (Senate Bill 1440, now codified in
	California Education Code sections 66746-66749) guarantees admission to a California
	State University (CSU) campus for any community college student who completes
	an “associate degree for transfer”, a newly established variation of the associate degrees
	traditionally offered at a California community college. The Associate in Arts for
	Transfer (AA-T) or the Associate in Science for Transfer (AS-T) is intended for students
	who plan to complete a bachelor's degree in a similar major at a CSU campus. Students
	completing these degrees (AA-T or AS-T) are guaranteed admission to the CSU system,
	but not to a particular campus or major. In order to earn one of these degrees, students
	must complete a minimum of 60 required semester units of CSU-transferable coursework
	with a minimum GPA of 2.0. Students transferring to a CSU campus that does accept the
	AA-T or AS-T will be required to complete no more than 60 units after transfer to earn a
	bachelor’s degree (unless the major is a designated “high-unit” major).
	 
	De Anza College seeks Board approval for application to the State Chancellor’s Office for a new
	degree developed based on Transfer Model Curriculum in order to fulfill the requirements set
	forth in SB1440 Legislation. The following application is being made for state approval:
	 
Associate in Arts in English (AA-T)
	 
	De Anza’s Curriculum Committee has approved this Associate Degree for Transfer.
	 
	 
	 
Submitted by:
					Brian Murphy, President, ext. 8705
Additional contact names:
					Anu Khanna, Faculty Curriculum Co-Chair, ext 5787
Is backup provided?
					Yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza President Brian Murphy recommends approval.
items.item_text: De Anza College Associate Degree for Transfer & State Approval
items.item_text_raw: 7. De Anza College Associate Degree for Transfer & State Approval

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
	 
	Trustee Swenson was unable to attend the regular Board of Trustees meeting of December
	10, 2012, due to a change in the meeting date necessitated by the Santa Clara County
	Registrar of Voters’ election certification timetable. As stated in Education Code
	§72024(d):
	 
	A member may be paid for any meeting when absent if the board, by
	resolution duly adopted and included in its minutes, finds that, at the time
	of the meeting, he or she is performing services outside the meeting for
	the community college district, he or she was ill or on jury duty, or the
	absence was due to a hardship deemed acceptable by the board. The
	compensation shall be a charge against the funds of the district.
	 
	Included for adoption by the Board is a resolution verifying the circumstances of trustee
	Swenson’s absence as required by Education Code Section 72024(d).
	 
	 
Submitted by:
					Linda Thor, extension 6104
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
					No
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt the resolution pursuant to Education Code Section 72024(d).
items.item_text: Resolution Authorizing Trustee Absence for Bruce Swenson
items.item_text_raw: 9. Resolution Authorizing Trustee Absence for Bruce Swenson

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
	 
	Temporary student restrooms will be required when the District Office Building personnel
	occupy the existing trailers in Parking Lots 5 & 6 as swing space while the District Office
	Building (DOB) begins construction and is under renovation. District staff will occupy the
	existing restroom trailer. Therefore, a quote was solicited from Mobile Modular Inc. (Mobile
	Modular) for the lease of a 12’ x 40’ relocatable, modular restroom structure for an 18-month
	period to accommodate the DOB construction schedule.
	 
	The total 18-month price to lease the DSA approved 12’ x 40’ relocatable, modular restroom is
	$32,482.41. This price includes delivery, installation, skirting, flooring, wood foundations, fire
	extinguishers, and ramps. The price also includes the costs to dismantle and return the building
	at the end of the 18-month term. The insurance value of the restroom is $60,672.00. If the
	District were to purchase the restroom, the total costs would be $72,235.72. Measure E will fund
	the project.
	 
	Public Contract Code 20652 allows the governing board of any community college district,
	without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be of the best interests of
	the district, to issue purchase orders based upon a competitive bid by any public corporation or
	agency, including any county, city, town, or district in order to lease or purchase equipment,
	materials, supplies, or other personal property for the district.
	 
	Based upon competitive bids, Franklin McKinley School District previously awarded a contract
	for modular buildings to McGrath Rent Corporation dba Mobile Modular Inc. As part of the
	contract, Mobile Modular agreed that other school districts are entitled to lease modular
	buildings at the same prices as Franklin McKinley School District. Modular buildings which
	meet the need to provide temporary restrooms are available from Mobile Modular based upon
	Franklin McKinley Bid #1298.
	 
	Furthermore, pursuant to Education Code 81526 “(a) The governing board of a community
	college district may lease relocatable structures for a term extending to the expected duration of
	use by the district, but not to exceed 10 years. (b) Any lease agreement or contract entered into
	pursuant to this section shall be initiated by resolution authorizing such action and prescribing
	the terms thereof adopted by vote of a majority of the members of the governing board.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
					Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
					Charles Allen, Art Heinrich
Is backup provided?
					Yes
items.item_text: Approval of Lease Agreement with Mobile Modular Inc.
items.item_text_raw: 10. Approval of Lease Agreement with Mobile Modular Inc.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
	 
	Temporary office space will be required for the Disability Resource Center personnel to use as
	swing space while Building #5800 is being renovated under Project #105 - Modernization of
	Learning Support Center, Biology and General Classrooms (Bldgs. #5100, #5400, #5600, #5700
	and #5800). Although the Disability Resource Center is currently located in Building #5800, the
	program will relocate into the newly renovated Building #5400. A quote was solicited from
	Mobile Modular Inc. (Mobile Modular) for the lease of a 48’ x 40’ relocatable, modular structure
	for a 22-month period to accommodate the project’s construction schedule.
	 
	The total 22-month price to lease the DSA approved 48’ x 40’ relocatable modular is
	$103,403.60. This price includes delivery, installation, skirting, flooring, wood foundations, fire
	extinguishers, and ramps. The price also includes the costs to dismantle and return the building
	at the end of the 22-month term. The insurance value of the structure is $96,000.00. The project
	will be funded by Measure C. If the District were to purchase the building the cost would be
	$155,573.20. The District at this time does not believe it will need the trailers beyond the 22-
	month lease.
	 
	Public Contract Code 20652 allows the governing board of any community college district,
	without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be of the best interests of
	the district, to issue purchase orders based upon a competitive bid by any public corporation or
	agency, including any county, city, town, or district in order to lease or purchase equipment,
	materials, supplies, or other personal property for the district.
	 
	Based upon competitive bids, Franklin McKinley School District previously awarded a contract
	for modular buildings to McGrath Rent Corporation dba Mobile Modular Inc. As part of the
	contract, Mobile Modular agreed that other school districts are entitled to lease modular
	buildings at the same prices as Franklin McKinley School District. Modular buildings that meet
	the need to provide temporary space are available from Mobile Modular based upon Franklin
	McKinley Bid #1298.
	 
	Furthermore, pursuant to Education Code 81526 “(a) The governing board of a community
	college district may lease relocatable structures for a term extending to the expected duration of
	use by the district, but not to exceed 10 years. (b) Any lease agreement or contract entered into
	pursuant to this section shall be initiated by resolution authorizing such action and prescribing
	the terms thereof adopted by vote of a majority of the members of the governing board.”
	 
	 
Submitted by:
					Gina Bailey, ext. 6165
Additional contact names:
					Charles Allen, ext. 6150, Art Heinrich, ext. 6295, Annette Perez, ext 6163
Is backup provided?
					Yes
